statement.text: Endovascular Aortic Repair (EVAR) is a minimally invasive technique for treating abdominal aortic aneurysms by deploying a stent-graft through femoral artery access. It excludes the aneurysm from systemic pressure while maintaining blood flow through the graft lumen. EVAR offers lower perioperative mortality than open repair but requires lifelong surveillance for endoleaks and device complications.
statement.formal: EVAR: Percutaneous/cutdown femoral access → Guidewire/catheter advancement → Stent-graft deployment → Aneurysm sac exclusion | Advantages: Reduced early mortality, shorter ICU/hospital stay | Trade-offs: Requires surveillance, risk of endoleak, reintervention

explanation.intuition: Instead of opening the abdomen and sewing in a new piece of artery, EVAR works like putting a sleeve inside the weakened aorta. Through small cuts in the groin, doctors thread a compressed stent-graft up to the aneurysm, then expand it like a self-opening umbrella. Blood now flows through the new graft, taking pressure off the weakened aneurysm wall. It's like putting a protective pipe inside a leaky pipe.
explanation.key_insight: EVAR trades early mortality benefit for late complications. The DREAM and EVAR-1 trials showed EVAR has ~1-2% early mortality vs 3-5% for open repair, but by 5-10 years, survival curves converge as EVAR patients experience more reinterventions and late ruptures. Patient selection is key: EVAR may be ideal for high-risk patients who need immediate survival benefit, while open repair may be better for young, fit patients who can tolerate a more durable procedure.
explanation.technical_details: Standard EVAR requires suitable anatomy: adequate proximal landing zone (infrarenal neck ≥10-15mm length, ≤32mm diameter, ≤60° angulation), access vessels ≥7mm for most devices, adequate distal landing in iliacs. The procedure involves: (1) bilateral femoral access (cutdown or percutaneous), (2) placement of stiff guidewire across aneurysm, (3) main body deployment from infrarenal neck to one iliac, (4) contralateral limb connection, (5) balloon molding of seal zones, (6) completion angiography. Current devices include modular bifurcated grafts (Cook, Gore, Medtronic, Endologix). Complex anatomy may require fenestrated or branched EVAR.
common_misconceptions: EVAR is easier than open surgery - technically demanding with significant learning curve
EVAR is always better than open repair - open repair has better long-term durability
Once EVAR is done, treatment is complete - requires lifelong surveillance
All AAAs can be treated with EVAR - anatomy must be suitable, ~50% of AAAs qualify

definitions_glossary.stent_graft: Self-expanding or balloon-expandable covered stent to exclude aneurysm
definitions_glossary.landing_zone: Normal aortic segment where graft seals, above and below aneurysm
definitions_glossary.proximal_neck: Segment of normal aorta between renal arteries and aneurysm
definitions_glossary.modular_design: Multi-piece device assembled in situ (main body + limbs)
definitions_glossary.fenestrated_evar: Device with holes for visceral arteries in difficult anatomy
definitions_glossary.branched_evar: Device with side branches for visceral/renal arteries

standard: AAA ≥4.5 cm with rapid expansion (>1 cm/year)
expanded: Ruptured AAA (if stable enough for CT)

iliac_landing.length: ≥15 mm in common iliac or external iliac with hypogastric coverage

indications_for_intervention: Type II endoleak with sac growth >5 mm

definition.@value: Minimally invasive procedure using stent-graft to exclude AAA from systemic circulation

sources.citation: EVAR Trial Participants. Endovascular aneurysm repair versus open repair in patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm (EVAR trial 1). Lancet. 2005;365:2179-2186.
SVS Practice Guidelines for EVAR Follow-up. J Vasc Surg. 2018.

learning_objectives: Describe the principles and technique of EVAR
List anatomic requirements for standard EVAR
Compare EVAR vs open repair outcomes
Understand the rationale for lifelong surveillance
clinical_pearls: EVAR trades early mortality for late complications
About 50% of AAAs have suitable anatomy for standard EVAR
Type I and III endoleaks need urgent intervention; Type II is usually observed
CT surveillance is mandatory - don't lose these patients to follow-up
